transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.content: And then once you get your GED which is a pretty big deal, did you then start getting into other programs here at Angola?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I started doing other programs. Getting into sober group and anger management classes like and signing up for them. It'll take you a little while to get in some of them. I started just getting into different programs. Just trying to improve both myself and improve my records.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was the goal in your mind? What was the motivation for doing that?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: The motivation was I had hope in my heart one day that things would change. That I would receive a chance to get paroled.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. And what? You wanted to be ready?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I wanted to be ready. I want to make sure that if I ever got the opportunity to present myself to a board or talk to anyone that they couldn't look back and say, "Well you've been here all these years. You ain't did nothing?" I accomplished a lot.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about those things. Tell me about them.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Oh well after I got through with school, I started getting a lot of certificates, taking a lot of classes. I also enrolled in NOBTS. I'm graduated. I have my associates and what's the other one I forgot? Bachelor's? My associates and my bachelor's in Christian Ministry.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When did you get that?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Oh I'm actually going to walk in December.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh my goodness. Well congratulations!

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Thank you. So I am a minister an inmate Minister. I get a chance to talk with a lot of the guys in here. I also work in the re-entry shack which is a place they bill money, we cook food and everything for a lot of the population and security and the money that's received what we do is we help a lot of the guys in reentry that's fixing to go home, that have jobs in certain areas like mechanics, HVAC, welding, we help them buy their uniforms. We help them buy the tools that they need to start a life when you get back out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. Tell me about ministry. What do you find what's the most challenging part of ministering to other inmates here?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: It's not so much as challenging and dealing with other inmates. It's more challenging with security allowing you to do what you have to do. Like if you put go to the blocks it's kind of hard sometimes getting in the blocks. And somebody may say you were like, somebody need to see you in the blocks and when you go over there and try to talk with him the security is like, "Hey we ain't letting nobody here right now," Or "We starting the showers right now," Or "We fixing to let the yard out right now," Or "We busy right now. We ain't got time right now." So it's more challenging in that aspect.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Get access.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Just to get access to them. But so far as the guys that's in the yard and the yards around us we can always talk with them. On the West Yard out on the side to the West Yard, I go over there on Sundays. We go every other Sunday now. And it's easy. It's simple man because I've been here a long time. So a lot of people already know me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. What do they want to talk about for the most part do you find?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Their life in general. They feel like there's no hope for them. The reason why the drugs and everything that the things that they're doing, they always try to come up with a good reason to have phones, cell phones, and stuff like that and they end up getting in trouble.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I try to tell him. "It's not, I understand how you want to get in contact with your family or I understand you want to get high to escape the prison scene, and everything. But once you come back down you still here. So why not use your time wisely. Put all that to the side right now and just straighten up for a while."

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Most of the folks that you minister to, are they also serving a life sentence?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: A lot of them are. The majority of people here are serving a lot of time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah they are.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Anybody with I think maybe less than 50 years, they try to send him to another prison. A satellite prison.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Most of the folks here are serving very long sentences. Well so if you're trying to do that you must have thought about how you've dealt with your own hopelessness, right? So at some point I expect that maybe somebody ministered to you?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But when you think about I know that you're getting ready for a clemency hearing and things are moving in the right direction with some of that but you're also seeing a lot of people who end up in Point Lookout, on kind of a monthly basis. Do you think about the prospect of not getting out and when you do how do you cope with it?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I do think about it. I look at the reality that everybody's not getting out of prison. You still will have people that will die here. They may be buried at Point Lookout. You have people that die here with family members coming and get their bodies. It's a reality.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: You just have to understand it. I understand it. What I do know that regardless of whatever happened that I do have peace with myself. And there's a saying that they say around here, "It is what it is." I mean I know God has forgiven me for my sins. I try to keep on a good relationship with God and I try to live the best day I can every day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Well what else can you do?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: What else can you do?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah sure it is what it is as you say.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I may walk out of here in a few minutes and have a heart attack. So it may not be just the board that turned me down for being here. It may be my health or something. Anything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure I understand. It sounds to me like you have made the best of all the opportunities that Angola has to offer while you're here. Another thing that I do hear people say is that, "Well there's some things I can't control, but I can control the way I live here." And this is a community and you're ministering to that community.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I mean it's a sense I guess I just want you to think that I'm saying anything you would do here is meaningless. The only thing you can do is to get out and have a meaningful life. But I think I see a lot of people living a very meaningful life here.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about you there's two families that get impacted when these things happen and yours is the other one. How has this affected your family?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: My family they pretty much understand what it was I went through. I know and by me keeping in more contact with my sister I know it's like a lot of things that she go through that she would wish that I would be there where she would be able to freely talk to me. Because when she'd go through some certain things and I may not call for a week, she may not be feeling that way at that time. What I'm saying so it is kind of strenuous on that end.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: It affects her in a lot of ways like when my mom passed away. She needed, she would tell me all the time, "Man I wish you would be here to help out." And the only thing I could do was encourage her but I don't want to be wanting to call her every day because of the phone bills. We pay little higher than normal people would pay who are free. So I would try to call her maybe once a week. At that time when I know she was going through some certain things I tried to call her once a week right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How did your mother handle you being incarcerated for this long?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Well I don't think no mother wants to see their kids in prison. She always kept up a good front but I think deep down she didn't want to see her kid locked up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Of course not. Do you remember was she able to come here and visit you? Do you remember the last time you saw her? Your last interaction with her?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Yes. It's been a while. She passed away in 2010. 2010. She passed away. So maybe about a year before that in 2009 was the last time I saw her. And kind of took a seat and she had caught a stroke. So it was kind of hard for her to talk. She had lost her talking ability. Apparently she got paralyzed on one side. So if I would call and talk to my sister she would put the phone to her ear and I would just tell her I love her. Things like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah the thing about visiting, it's kind of a double edged sword because it's obviously joyful to see loved ones but then you've got to see them go.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Yeah. My niece and nephew they do that now when they come, they have so much fun because I play with them and rough them up a little bit. When it's time to go it's like, "We don't want to go! We don't want to go!" I say to them, "Oh I'll be back!"

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So this may seem like an odd question because you're here in prison, but I think that the challenges of prison probably change over time like when you're first here there are different things that are challenging and over time you get used to something. What's the worst part of the prison experience for you now?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Oh I think it would be mostly not being able to see family members that you don't have contact with. I think it would be sex. I'm going to throw that down there. Not being able to have sex. Let's see. I think that would be, because I'm at an age where I want to stay in contact with all my family members.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: And there's some that it's kind of hard to get in contact with. You can't make them write to you, you can't make them e-mail you on the machine, you can't make them accept your calls, you can't make them do anything. All I can do is kind of like go through my sister or my brother or my father and tell them I said, "Hey, if they want to get in contact with me." And give them the information on how to do that. That's about the hardest part right there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you like the rodeo?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: It's okay. It's an opportunity to get away from down here. And you kind of go out there kind of sit down and talk with everybody. A lot of free world people. Kind of escape the prison life, and the conversations about prison. You get tired of that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I get it. Do you work in the hobby shop and sell things there or not?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I'm in the hobby shop. I don't sell anything anymore. I kind of gave it up I used to make chairs, do woodworker stuff.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Not anymore?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Not Anymore.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What are you most proud of the various things you've accomplished over the years? What stands out as the thing you're most proud of?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I'm proud of myself for getting my education. I'm proud of being more wise. I'm proud of myself for being more positive. I'm proud of myself for staying out of trouble. I'm proud of myself for doing the best that I can in dealing with my family and my friends.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I'm proud of myself that I'm not selfish. I'm able to help when I can. I'm proud of myself for not just doing my time for me but for doing my time for others as well. What I mean by trying to talk with them and help them out. Just by being an ear sometimes and trying to put myself in the right position. And being the right character. So they could come and talk to them when they want that because sometimes you have people that say they want to be available to you.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: But every time you come up it's like, "I don't want to talk to you. I ain't got time right now." Or your face may say, "I don't want to be here. I don't want to hear this." So I try to be in right character at all times to make myself available for anybody that needs to talk with me Yeah so I'm proud of that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. And going through Bible College is a pretty big deal. Not everybody gets to do that.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Yeah I was thankful for that.

transcript.content: What's your mother's name?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Judy.

transcript.content: And your sister's name?

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: April.

transcript.content: Who's Jessica?

transcript.speaker: Neal

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: So we had a good time. We always talked and everything. I asked her if she wanted to marry me. She said yeah. And I told her, "Hey, it's not easy." My situation is not easy. It was mostly dealing with my family, when my mama took sick and her and my sister begin to fight and get into a lot of physical fights, and verbal. Because all of them still all live together. My mom, my sister, and my wife.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh in Beaumont.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Oh no actually my mom had moved to Natchitoches, Louisiana when she began to get real sick because she had, what would you call it? Some kind of medical plan with.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I'm not sure. Why don't you go ahead make sure? It's Neal Spencer.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Cypress Four. I didn't know it was that late.

transcript.content: She moved to Negreet.

transcript.content: No my mom moved to Natchitoches so she could be a little more closer to me. After my sister graduated school and everything.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: Or I can end up going to Houston with my sister and just staying with her and her husband and kids. She's got two kids and until I'm able to get myself situated where I can buy my own apartment or home or whatever and save money and everything.

transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: I would really like to try to open up my own business. Maybe doing barbecue. Barbecuing. I love to cook. transcript.speaker: Neal
transcript.content: So I wouldn't be like, I was hiring them to come out and do anything but it would be like if you want to raise revenue or funds for your church you have y'all could come out, do what y'all do here. transcript.content: Have a job opening, have job openings for the teenagers and stuff that's coming up where they could save money to help them buy their school clothes or whatever help mom pay for bills or whatever they need.
